290: :label: rem-metric-regularity
291: 
292: Since $\Phi$ is strictly concave with $H_{\Phi}(x) \preceq -\kappa I$, we have $-H_{\Phi}(x) \succeq \kappa I \succ 0$. Thus, the emergent metric tensor:
293: 
294: $$
295: g(x) := (-H_{\Phi}(x) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1}
296: $$
297: 
298: is positive definite and well-defined for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. The metric satisfies:
299: 
300: $$
301: \kappa^{-1} I \preceq g(x) \preceq (\kappa + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}})^{-1} I
302: $$

items.label: rem-ascent-interpretation
items.title: Physical Interpretation: Collective Gradient Ascent
items.content:
308: :label: rem-ascent-interpretation
309: 
310: The geometric ascent operator encodes **collective fitness optimization** in the emergent Riemannian geometry:
311: 
312: 1. **Collective Potential:** $\Psi = \frac{1}{\beta}\log \sum_j e^{\beta \Phi(x_j)}$ is the smooth maximum (log-sum-exp) of all walker fitness values, providing a global measure of swarm quality.
313: 
314: 2. **Weighted Gradient:** Each walker $i$ moves along $\nabla_{x_i} \Psi = p_i \nabla \Phi(x_i)$, where $p_i = \frac{e^{\beta\Phi(x_i)}}{\sum_k e^{\beta\Phi(x_k)}}$. High-fitness walkers have larger weights and contribute more to the collective ascent.
315: 
316: 3. **Riemannian Ascent:** The metric tensor $g = (-H_\Phi + \varepsilon I)^{-1}$ preconditions the gradient, creating a **second-order optimization method** (natural gradient) that accounts for the landscape's curvature. This curvature generates the **Yang-Mills gauge fields** (Section 4).

items.label: rem-noise-anisotropy
items.title: Anisotropic Position Noise vs. Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Velocity Dynamics
items.content:
366: :label: rem-noise-anisotropy
367: 
368: The position noise is **anisotropic** and **state-dependent**, scaled by $\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x)$, which is the inverse square root of the regularized Hessian. This coupling between diffusion and geometry is **Axiom V (Geometrization of Information)** from the foundational framework.
369: 
370: In contrast, the velocity update follows **Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) dynamics** with friction coefficient $\gamma_{\text{fric}}$. This is the "O-step" of the **BAOAB integrator** used in molecular dynamics. The OU process has:
371: - **Friction term**: $c_1 v_i' = e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t} v_i'$ (exponential decay toward zero)
372: - **Noise term**: $c_2 \xi_i^{(v)} = \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}} \xi_i^{(v)}$ (Gaussian fluctuation)
373: - **Invariant measure**: $\pi(v) \propto \exp(-\|v\|^2/(2\sigma_v^2))$ (Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution)
374: - **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$ (exponential convergence to equilibrium)
375: 
376: The friction term is **crucial** for establishing a spectral gap in velocity space. Without it, free Brownian motion has continuous spectrum with no gap.
377: 
378: The anisotropic position noise ensures that:
379: - In directions of high curvature (large $|-H_{\Phi}|$), diffusion is suppressed
380: - In directions of low curvature (small $|-H_{\Phi}|$), diffusion is enhanced

items.label: rem-cg-sde-connection
items.title: Connection to SDEs
items.content:
386: :label: rem-cg-sde-connection
387: 
388: In the continuous-time limit $\Delta t \to 0$, the Crystalline Gas dynamics formally converge to a system of coupled stochastic differential equations (SDEs):
389: 
390: $$
391: \begin{aligned}
392: \mathrm{d}x_i &= v_i \, \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_x \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i) \, \mathrm{d}W_i^{(x)} + \eta \, g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i} \Psi(x) \, \mathrm{d}t \\
393: \mathrm{d}v_i &= -\gamma_{\text{fric}} v_i \, \mathrm{d}t + \sigma_v \sqrt{2\gamma_{\text{fric}}} \, \mathrm{d}W_i^{(v)}
394: \end{aligned}
395: $$
396: 
397: where:
398: - $W_i^{(x)}, W_i^{(v)}$ are independent $d$-dimensional Brownian motions
399: - $\Psi(x) = \frac{1}{\beta}\log\sum_{j=1}^N e^{\beta\Phi(x_j)}$ is the log-sum-exp collective potential
400: - $g(x_i) = (-H_{\Phi}(x_i) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1}$ is the emergent Riemannian metric
401: - $\nabla_{x_i} \Psi = p_i \nabla\Phi(x_i)$ with $p_i = \frac{e^{\beta\Phi(x_i)}}{\sum_k e^{\beta\Phi(x_k)}}$
402: - The friction term $-\gamma_{\text{fric}} v_i$ ensures **velocity confinement** (necessary for spectral gap)
403: 
404: The velocity equation is an **Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process** with invariant measure $\pi(v) \propto \exp(-\|v\|^2/(2\sigma_v^2))$ and spectral gap $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$.

items.title: Simplicity of Convergence Proof
items.content:
588: :label: rem-cg-convergence-simplicity
589: 
590: The convergence proof for the Crystalline Gas is **elementary** and relies on standard techniques:
591: 
592: 1. **No Cloning:** The algorithm has no genealogical structure, avoiding population dynamics
593: 2. **Deterministic Ascent:** The geometric ascent is a standard gradient flow with well-understood convergence properties
594: 3. **Standard Lyapunov Theory:** The proof reduces to verifying a single drift inequality, which follows from elementary estimates

items.label: rem-cg-gauge-force-interpretation
items.title: Physical Interpretation of Gauge Force
items.content:
899: :label: rem-cg-gauge-force-interpretation
900: 
901: The gauge force has a natural interpretation:
902: 
903: 1. **Color Matching:** The force compares the color observable $|\Psi_i\rangle$ at site $i$ with the transported observable $U_{ij}|\Psi_j\rangle$ from neighbor $j$
904: 
905: 2. **Parallel Transport:** The link variable $U_{ij}$ "rotates" the color vector $|\Psi_j\rangle$ from $j$'s local color basis to $i$'s local color basis before comparison
906: 
907: 3. **Attractive/Repulsive:** When $U_{ij}|\Psi_j\rangle$ and $|\Psi_i\rangle$ are similar, the force is small (walkers are "color-aligned"). When they differ, the force drives alignment.

items.content:
1058: :label: rem-cg-edge-vs-node-centric
1059: 
1060: The edge-centric framework resolves the critical flaw of the node-centric approach:
1061: 
1062: **Node-Centric (Old, Invalid):**
1063: - Gauge field derived from walker observables: $A_\mu \sim \varphi_i(x_i, v_i)$
1064: - One-way causality: Walkers → Field (no feedback)
1065: - Gauge transformations have no physical effect
1066: - **Not a true gauge theory**
1067: 
1068: **Edge-Centric (New, Valid):**
1069: - Gauge field $\{U_{ij}\}$ is fundamental, independent of walker states
1070: - Two-way causality: Walkers ↔ Field (feedback loop)
1071: - Force law depends explicitly on $\{U_{ij}\}$ via parallel transport
1072: - Field evolves via Wilson action minimization
1073: - **True gauge theory with full covariance**

items.title: Comparison with Standard Lattice Gauge Theory
items.content:
1115: :label: rem-cg-vs-lattice-qcd
1116: 
1117: The Crystalline Gas is a variant of Lattice Gauge Theory with key differences:
1118: 
1119: **Standard Lattice QCD:**
1120: - Fixed cubic lattice in Euclidean spacetime
1121: - Link variables $U_{\mu}(x)$ on edges of the lattice
1122: - Wilson action with plaquettes
1123: - Static lattice structure
1124: 
1125: **Crystalline Gas:**
1126: - **Dynamic lattice** defined by walker positions (changes with time)
1127: - Link variables $U_{ij}$ on edges of the walker graph
1128: - Same Wilson action functional
1129: - Lattice evolves according to fitness landscape
1130: 
1131: **Advantage:** The dynamic lattice provides a natural mechanism for the lattice to explore configuration space, potentially accessing configurations that fixed-lattice Monte Carlo might miss.

items.label: rem-cg-area-law-to-mass-gap
items.title: From Area Law to Mass Gap
items.content:
1174: :label: rem-cg-area-law-to-mass-gap
1175: 
1176: The area law is the **hallmark of confinement** in gauge theories. It implies:
1177: 
1178: 1. **Confinement:** Color charges cannot be separated to infinite distance (potential grows linearly with separation)
1179: 
1180: 2. **Mass Gap:** The two-point correlation function decays exponentially:
1181:    $$
1182:    \langle A_\mu^a(x) A_\nu^b(y) \rangle \sim \exp(-m_{\text{gap}} \|x - y\|)
1183:    $$
1184:    where $m_{\text{gap}} > 0$ is the mass of the lightest glueball
1185: 
1186: 3. **Quantitative Bound:** From the spectral gap $\lambda_0$ ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap`), we derive:
1187:    $$
1188:    m_{\text{gap}} \geq \frac{\lambda_0}{3\sigma_v\sqrt{d}}
1189:    $$
1190:    where $\sigma_v$ is the walker velocity scale

1222: :label: rem-cg-gauge-extensions
1223: 
1224: The CMI Yang-Mills Millennium Problem specifically requires proving existence and mass gap for gauge group SU(N) with $N \geq 2$. **Our edge-centric SU(3) construction in Section 4.2 fully satisfies this requirement.**

1229: 1. Add SU(2) link variables $V_{ij} \in \text{SU}(2)$ on the walker graph
1230: 2. Add U(1) phase variables $\theta_{ij} \in \text{U}(1)$ on edges
1231: 3. Extend the Wilson action to include all three gauge groups
1232: 4. Extend the gauge-covariant force law to include all interactions

items.content:
1412: :label: rem-discrete-vs-continuous
1413: 
1414: The Bakry-Émery criterion (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-bakry-emery`) is stated for **continuous-time diffusions**. For discrete-time Markov chains like Crystalline Gas, we must either:
1415: 
1416: 1. **Pass to continuous-time limit** ($\Delta t \to 0$) and apply Bakry-Émery to the limiting SDE, then bound the discrete chain's spectral gap in terms of the continuous limit.
1417: 
1418: 2. **Use Foster-Lyapunov** (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov`) which applies directly to discrete chains.
1419: 
1420: 3. **Use discrete Bakry-Émery** variants (e.g., Caputo et al. 2009) which extend the $\Gamma_2$ calculus to finite-difference operators.

items.title: Spectral Gap with Gauge Field Dynamics
items.content:
1636: :label: rem-cg-gauge-field-spectral-gap
1637: 
1638: **Extended State Space**: With the edge-centric SU(3) framework ({prf:ref}`def-cg-link-variables`), the full system state space is:
1639: 
1640: $$
1641: \Omega_{\text{full}} = \Sigma_N \times \mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{E}}
1642: $$
1643: 
1644: where:
1645: - $\Sigma_N = (\mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ is the walker phase space (positions + velocities)
1646: - $\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{E}} = \{U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3) : (i,j) \in \mathcal{E}\}$ is the gauge field configuration space (link variables on edges)
1647: 
1648: The full generator decomposes as:
1649: 
1650: $$
1651: L_{\text{full}} = L_{\text{walkers}} + L_{\text{links}}
1652: $$
1653: 
1654: where:
1655: - $L_{\text{walkers}}$ is the walker dynamics analyzed above (matter force + thermal noise)
1656: - $L_{\text{links}}$ is the gauge field relaxation dynamics ({prf:ref}`def-cg-field-update`)
1657: 
1658: **Key Observation**: The link variable dynamics are **local relaxation** to minimize the Wilson action ({prf:ref}`def-cg-wilson-action`). This is a fast local equilibration process: each $U_{ij}$ relaxes to minimize $S_W[\{U_{ij}\}]$ via gradient descent on SU(3).
1659: 
1660: **Timescale Separation**: Gauge field relaxation is typically much faster than walker diffusion:
1661: - **Link updates**: Local optimization on compact manifold SU(3) → fast convergence (timescale $\sim \alpha_{\text{gauge}}^{-1}$)
1662: - **Walker dynamics**: Global exploration of $\mathbb{R}^d$ → slower convergence (timescale $\sim \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{-1}$)
1663: 
1664: When $\alpha_{\text{gauge}} \gg \lambda_{\text{gap}}$, the gauge field equilibrates instantaneously relative to walker motion. In this regime, the link variables "slave" to the walker configuration, and the full system spectral gap is dominated by the walker spectral gap:
1665: 
1666: $$
1667: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{full}} \approx \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{walkers}} = \lambda_0
1668: $$
1669: 
1670: **Rigorous Lower Bound**: Even without assuming timescale separation, the spectral gap for the walker degrees of freedom provides a **lower bound** for the full system:
1671: 
1672: $$
1673: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{full}} \geq \lambda_0 \wedge \lambda_{\text{gauge}}
1674: $$
1675: 
1676: where $\lambda_{\text{gauge}}$ is the spectral gap for link variable relaxation. Since $\lambda_{\text{gauge}} > 0$ (SU(3) is compact and Wilson action is bounded below), the full system possesses a uniform spectral gap.

items.title: Wilson Loops in the Edge-Centric Framework
items.content:
1722: :label: rem-cg-wilson-loop-edge-centric
1723: 
1724: In the edge-centric SU(3) framework ({prf:ref}`def-cg-link-variables`), Wilson loops are constructed directly from the link variables $U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3)$ on the walker information graph.
1725: 
1726: **Construction**: Let $\mathcal{C} = (i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_n, i_1)$ be a closed path on the walker graph (a sequence of connected edges). The **Wilson loop** around $\mathcal{C}$ is:
1727: 
1728: $$
1729: W_{\mathcal{C}} := \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})
1730: $$
1731: 
1732: where the **path-ordered product** is:
1733: 
1734: $$
1735: U_{\mathcal{C}} := U_{i_1 i_2} \cdot U_{i_2 i_3} \cdots U_{i_{n-1} i_n} \cdot U_{i_n i_1}
1736: $$
1737: 
1738: **Key Properties**:
1739: 1. **Gauge Invariance**: Under local gauge transformation $G: i \mapsto G_i \in \text{SU}(3)$, the link variables transform as $U_{ij} \to G_i U_{ij} G_j^\dagger$ ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-gauge-covariance`). The Wilson loop transforms as:
1740: 
1741:    $$
1742:    U_{\mathcal{C}} \to G_{i_1} U_{\mathcal{C}} G_{i_1}^\dagger
1743:    $$
1744: 
1745:    Therefore $\text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})$ is **gauge-invariant**: $\text{Tr}(G_{i_1} U_{\mathcal{C}} G_{i_1}^\dagger) = \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}})$ ✓
1746: 
1747: 2. **Area Enclosed**: For a closed path on the walker graph, the **minimal area** $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$ is the area of the minimal surface in $\mathbb{R}^3$ whose boundary is the walker positions $\{x_{i_1}, x_{i_2}, \ldots, x_{i_n}\}$.
1748: 
1749: 3. **Wilson Action**: The Wilson action ({prf:ref}`def-cg-wilson-action`) penalizes field configurations where Wilson loops around plaquettes deviate from the identity, driving the system toward confinement.

items.raw_directive:
4672: This unified definition handles both alive and dead walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`)s. For a **dead walker** $i \in \mathcal{D}_t$, its potential $V_{\text{fit},i} = 0$. Its cloning companion $c_{\text{clone}}(i)$ is drawn from the alive set ({prf:ref}`def-alive-dead-sets`) $\mathcal{A}_t$, making its potential $V_{\text{fit},c_{\text{clone}}(i)} > 0$. The score simplifies to $S_i = V_{\text{fit},c_{\text{clone}}(i)} / \varepsilon$. Since the **Global Constraint** $\varepsilon \cdot p_{\max} < \eta^{(\alpha+\beta)}$ is satisfied, the minimum possible score for a dead walker is guaranteed to be greater than the maximum possible threshold: $S_{i, \min} > (\eta^{\alpha+\beta})/\varepsilon > p_{\max}$. Because $T_{\text{clone}}$ is always sampled from $[0, p_{\max}]$, the condition $S_i > T_{\text{clone}}$ is always met. This results in a "Clone" action with probability 1, ensuring the revival mechanism remains an emergent and guaranteed property of the framework.
4673: :::
4674: :::{admonition} Randomness discipline for cloning
4675: :class: note
4676: - For each walker ({prf:ref}`def-walker`) $i$, independently sample the cloning companion index $c_{\text{clone}}(i)\sim \mathbb C_i(\mathcal S)$ (with replacement) using an independent uniform $U_i^{\mathrm{comp}}$.

118: :label: rem-fiber-bundle-structure
119: 
120: The state space $\Sigma_N$ is naturally a fiber bundle:
121: 
122: **Base Space**: The constrained node configuration space modulo rotations:
123: 
124: $$
125: \mathcal{B}_N := \left\{\mathbf{x} \in (\mathbb{R}^4)^N : \sum_{i=1}^N x_i = 0\right\} / SO(4)
126: $$
127: 
128: where we quotient by the rotation group SO(4) because the Hamiltonian depends only on relative coordinates $x_i - x_j$ and their norms, which are rotationally invariant.
129: 
130: **Fiber**: Over each node configuration $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{B}_N$, the gauge field lives in:
131: 
132: $$
133: \mathcal{F}(\mathbf{x}) := (\text{SU}(N_c))^{E_N(\mathbf{x})}
134: $$
135: 
136: The dimension of this fiber is $|E_N(\mathbf{x})| \cdot \dim(\text{SU}(N_c)) = |E_N(\mathbf{x})| \cdot (N_c^2 - 1)$, which varies with the graph structure.
137: 
138: **Singularities**: The fiber dimension changes at configurations where the Delaunay triangulation topology changes. In $\mathbb{R}^4$, such topology changes occur when $d+2 = 6$ points become co-spherical (lie on a common 3-sphere), causing a 4-simplex to "flip" and reconnect differently. These singularities form a measure-zero algebraic variety in $\mathbb{R}^{4N}$.
139: 
140: **Well-Posedness**: Despite these singularities, the dynamics and invariant measure are well-defined:
141: 1. The Hamiltonian $H(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{U})$ is smooth everywhere (depends only on distances and gauge fields)

items.title: Analogy to Classical Hypocoercivity Theory
items.content:
992: :class: tip
993: 
994: This structure is the **discrete stochastic analogue** of the classical hypocoercivity framework for kinetic PDEs (Villani, 2009; Dolbeault-Mouhot-Schmeiser, 2015):
995: 
996: **Classical Hypocoercivity (Kinetic Fokker-Planck)**:
997: - The transport operator $v \cdot \nabla_x$ generates dynamics in $x$ but is neutral on the velocity distribution.
998: - The collision operator $\mathcal{L}_v$ generates dissipation in $v$ but does not directly affect $x$.
999: - Neither operator alone contracts the full kinetic norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$.
1000: - The augmented norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \varepsilon \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$ allows proving exponential decay by balancing the operators' effects.
1001: 
1002: **Our Discrete Stochastic Framework (Fragile Gas)**:
1003: - The cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ contracts $V_{\text{Var}}$ (internal swarm structure) but may expand $W_h^2$ (inter-swarm distance via velocity resets).
1004: - The kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}$ contracts $W_h^2$ (via confining potential) but may expand $V_{\text{Var}}$ (via diffusion noise).
1005: - Neither operator alone contracts the full phase-space error.
1006: - The augmented Lyapunov $V_{\text{total}} = W_h^2 + c_V V_{\text{Var}} + c_B W_b$ allows proving exponential convergence by balancing the operators' synergistic dissipation.

items.title: Why Inter-Swarm Error Doesn't Contract Under Cloning
items.content:
8018: :label: rem-why-vw-expands
8019: 
8020: The cloning operator **cannot contract** $V_W$ because:
8021: 
8022: 1. **Intra-swarm mechanism:** Cloning acts **within** each swarm independently. It compares walker $i$ to its companion in the **same swarm**, not to the corresponding walker in the other swarm.
8023: 
8024: 2. **No inter-swarm communication:** The fitness evaluation and companion selection have no information about the other swarm in the coupled analysis. They cannot "know" which direction reduces $V_W$.
8025: 
8026: 3. **Stochastic desynchronization:** Even with synchronous coupling, different swarm configurations lead to different fitness landscapes, causing different cloning decisions that increase divergence.

items.label: rem-cg-su3-physical
items.title: Physical Interpretation of SU(3) Structure
items.content:
252: :label: rem-cg-su3-physical
253: 
254: The SU(3) color structure emerges naturally because:
255: 
256: 1. **Tensor product structure:** $F \otimes p$ is a rank-2 tensor in 3D space, naturally living in the adjoint representation of SU(3)
257: 
258: 2. **Traceless condition:** Removing the trace projects from U(3) to SU(3), ensuring no overall "baryon number" charge
259: 
260: 3. **8 gluons:** The 8 independent components of $T^{\text{traceless}}$ correspond exactly to the 8 gluons: $(r\bar{g}, r\bar{b}, g\bar{b}, \ldots)$
261: 
262: 4. **Coupling strength:** The amplitude $\rho_i = \|F\| \cdot \|p\|$ gives the **strong coupling constant**:
263: 
264: $$
265: g_s \propto \|F\| \cdot \|p\| \propto \|\nabla \Phi\| \cdot \|v\|
266: $$

386: :label: rem-cg-su2-nonabelian

397: 
398: $$

items.content:
497: :label: rem-cg-u1-alternative

507: This has the advantage of being **geometrically distinct** from the SU(2) structure (which uses direction, not distance), more closely mirroring the Fragile Gas construction.

items.label: rem-empirical-measures
items.title: Empirical Measures and Framework Properties
items.content:
198: :label: rem-empirical-measures
199: 
200: **Notational Precision**: This document analyzes the $N$-particle empirical measures $\mu_1, \mu_2$, which are discrete probability measures supported on $N$ walkers. The clustering algorithm, fitness function $F(x)$, and potential landscape are properties defined at the population level.
201: 
202: **Relationship to Continuum Limit**: The fitness function $F(x)$ and its valley structure are properties of the continuum state space $\mathcal{X}$, while the clusters $I_k, J_k$ are finite-sample objects constructed from the empirical distribution. The proofs in this document use properties of the limiting landscape (e.g., Confining Potential axiom, fitness valleys) to reason about finite-sample cluster behavior.
203: 
204: **Approximation Errors**: For finite $N$, there are approximation errors $O(1/\sqrt{N})$ when estimating continuum properties (like the potential $F(x)$) from empirical measures. These errors are absorbed into:
205: 1. The noise term $C_W = O(d\delta^2)$ in the contraction inequality
206: 2. The clustering threshold $\varepsilon$, which depends on $N$ implicitly through the error tolerance
207: 
208: **N-Uniformity Justification**: The key result is that these finite-sample approximation errors do not affect the *sign* or *N-independence* of the contraction constant $\kappa_W > 0$. This is because:
209: - The clustering algorithm thresholds (Definition 6.3) are calibrated to maintain $O(1)$ cluster fractions
210: - The framework axioms (Confining Potential, Environmental Richness) provide $O(1)$ landscape features that dominate the finite-sample noise
211: - All critical bounds ($f_{UH}, p_u, c_{\text{sep}}$) are proven N-uniform in [03_cloning](03_cloning) precisely to account for these approximation effects

items.content:
412: :label: rem-jitter-cancellation
413: 
414: The most powerful feature of this coupling is **jitter cancellation**. If walker $i$ clones in **both** swarms (which happens in Case A with consistent fitness ordering), then:
415: 
416: $$
417: \|x'_{1,i} - x'_{2,i}\|^2 = \|(x_{1,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i) - (x_{2,\pi(i)} + \zeta_i)\|^2 = \|x_{1,\pi(i)} - x_{2,\pi(i)}\|^2
418: $$
419: 
420: The jitter **cancels exactly** due to synchronization! This is the strongest form of contraction.

items.content:
1342: :class: important
1343: 
1344: **Critical clarification:** The hypocoercive contraction proven in this chapter uses **only**:
1345: 1. **Coercivity** of $U$ ({prf:ref}`axiom-confining-potential`) - confinement at infinity
1346: 2. **Lipschitz continuity** of forces on compact regions
1347: 3. **Friction-transport coupling** through the hypocoercive norm

1399: :label: rem-coupling-term-intuition
1400: 
1401: The coupling term $b\langle \Delta x, \Delta v \rangle$ is the key to hypocoercivity:
1402: 
1403: - **Without coupling** ($b = 0$): Position and velocity evolve independently in the norm. The degenerate noise in $v$ doesn't help regularize $x$.
1404: 
1405: - **With coupling** ($b \neq 0$): The cross term creates a "rotation" in the $(x,v)$ phase space. Even though noise only enters in $v$, the coupling allows dissipation to "leak" into the $x$ coordinate.

items.label: rem-qsd-vs-true-stationarity
items.title: QSD Stationarity vs. True Stationarity
items.content:
530: :label: rem-qsd-vs-true-stationarity
531: 
532: For a finite N-particle system, the Quasi-Stationary Distribution $\nu_N^{QSD}$ satisfies a **modified stationarity condition** that accounts for the non-zero probability of eventual extinction. For any test function $\Phi: \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}$:
533: 
534: $$
535: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}}[\mathcal{L}_N \Phi] = -\lambda_N \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{QSD}}[\Phi]
536: 
537: $$
538: 
539: where $\lambda_N > 0$ is the **extinction rate** (also called the survival rate or quasi-stationary eigenvalue). This rate characterizes how quickly the conditioned process escapes from the quasi-stationary state toward the absorbing boundary.

items.label: rem-uniqueness-completeness-constraint-set
items.title: Completeness of the Constraint Set $\mathcal{P}$
items.content:
900: :label: rem-uniqueness-completeness-constraint-set
901: 
902: The space $\mathcal{P}$ is a closed subset of the Banach space $H^1_w(\Omega)$, hence complete. This follows from:
903: 
904: 1. **Non-negativity**: The set $\{\rho \in H^1_w : \rho \ge 0 \text{ a.e.}\}$ is closed because if $\rho_n \to \rho$ in $H^1_w$, then $\rho_n \to \rho$ in $L^2_w$, and a subsequence converges almost everywhere. The limit of non-negative functions is non-negative a.e.
905: 
906: 2. **Normalization**: The set $\{\rho \in H^1_w : \int \rho = 1\}$ is closed because the functional $\rho \mapsto \int \rho dz$ is continuous with respect to the $H^1_w$ norm (by Sobolev embedding $H^1_w \hookrightarrow L^1$).
907: 
908: 3. **Intersection of closed sets**: $\mathcal{P}$ is the intersection of these two closed sets, hence closed.

items.title: Motivation and Justification
items.content:
951: :class: note
952: 
953: This axiom is the cornerstone of our LSI proof, as it enables the use of powerful optimal transport techniques:
954: 
955: 1. **HWI Inequality (Section 4.2):** The Otto-Villani inequality $H(\mu|\pi) \leq W_2(\mu,\pi)\sqrt{I(\mu|\pi)}$ requires log-concavity of $\pi$
956: 
957: 2. **Displacement Convexity** ({prf:ref}`lem-entropy-transport-dissipation`): McCann's displacement convexity of entropy along Wasserstein geodesics requires log-concavity of the reference measure
958: 
959: Without log-concavity, the entire entropy-transport Lyapunov function analysis (Section 5) becomes invalid.
960: 
961: **Heuristic Support:**
962: 
963: The axiom rests on the following observations:
964: 
965: - **Kinetic regularization:** The kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}$ preserves log-concavity. For a harmonic confining potential $U(x) = \frac{\kappa}{2}\|x - x^*\|^2$, the kinetic operator's invariant measure is explicitly log-concave (Gaussian):
966: 
967: $$
968: \pi_{\text{kin}}(x, v) = \mathcal{N}\left(x^*, \frac{\theta}{\kappa} I\right) \otimes \mathcal{N}(0, \theta I)
969: $$
970: 
971: - **Diffusive smoothing:** The Langevin dynamics component with Gaussian noise $\mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2 I)$ is a strongly regularizing operation that promotes log-concavity
972: 
973: - **Cloning as perturbation:** The cloning operator can be viewed as a small perturbation (controlled by cloning frequency and noise $\delta^2$) of the log-concave kinetic dynamics
974: 
975: The axiom conjectures that the regularizing effect of the kinetic operator is sufficiently strong to overcome any non-log-concave-preserving effects of the cloning operator.
976: 
977: **Potential Failure Modes:**
978: 
979: Critical examination reveals scenarios where this axiom is likely to fail:
980: 
981: 1. **Multi-modal fitness landscapes:** If the fitness function $g(x, v, S)$ induces a highly multi-modal or non-log-concave reward landscape (e.g., multiple disjoint high-reward regions), the cloning operator will concentrate mass in disconnected regions. This multi-peaked structure is fundamentally incompatible with log-concavity, which requires a single mode.
982: 
983: 2. **Excessive cloning rate:** If the cloning frequency is too high relative to the kinetic relaxation timescale, the resampling dynamics dominate the Langevin diffusion. The system has insufficient time to "re-convexify" between disruptive cloning events, allowing non-log-concave features to persist.
984: 
985: 3. **Insufficient post-cloning noise:** If $\delta^2$ (the variance of inelastic collision noise) is too small, cloned walkers remain tightly clustered near their parents, creating sharp local concentrations of probability mass. Such delta-function-like features are incompatible with smooth log-concave densities.
986: 
987: **Plausibility Condition:**
988: 
989: The axiom is most plausible in a **separation of timescales regime**:
990: 
991: Let $\tau_{\text{relax}}^{\text{kin}}$ be the characteristic relaxation time for the kinetic operator to approach its stationary measure, and let $\tau_{\text{clone}}$ be the average time between cloning events for a single walker. The axiom is expected to hold when:
992: 
993: $$
994: \tau_{\text{clone}} \gg \tau_{\text{relax}}^{\text{kin}}
995: $$
996: 
997: This condition ensures the system has sufficient time to re-equilibrate via kinetic diffusion between disruptive cloning steps.
998: 
999: **Connection to Model Parameters:**
1000: 
1001: This timescale separation can be expressed in terms of the model's physical parameters:
1002: 
1003: - **Kinetic relaxation rate:** Governed by $\lambda_{\text{kin}} = \min(\gamma, \kappa_{\text{conf}})$ where $\gamma$ is the friction coefficient and $\kappa_{\text{conf}}$ is the confinement strength. Thus $\tau_{\text{relax}}^{\text{kin}} \sim 1/\lambda_{\text{kin}}$.
1004: 
1005: - **Cloning timescale:** Inversely proportional to the average cloning probability $\bar{p}_{\text{clone}}$, which depends on the fitness function $g$ and the diversity of the swarm.
1006: 
1007: Therefore, the axiom is more plausible for:
1008: - **Strong friction** $\gamma \gg 1$ (fast velocity equilibration)
1009: - **Strong confinement** $\kappa_{\text{conf}} \gg 1$ (tight spatial concentration)
1010: - **Smooth fitness landscapes** where $g(x, v, S)$ is itself approximately log-concave
1011: - **Moderate cloning rates** ensuring $\bar{p}_{\text{clone}} \cdot \lambda_{\text{kin}}^{-1} \ll 1$
1012: 
1013: **Future Work:**
1014: 
1015: A rigorous proof or disproof of this axiom is a significant open problem. The focus should be on:
1016: 
1017: 1. **Defining the validity regime:** Rigorously characterize the parameter space $(\gamma, \kappa_{\text{conf}}, \delta^2, g)$ where log-concavity holds, using the timescale separation condition as a starting point
1018: 
1019: 2. **Perturbative analysis:** Prove log-concavity in the limit $\bar{p}_{\text{clone}} \to 0$ (cloning as rare perturbation) or $\kappa_{\text{conf}} \to \infty$ (extremely tight confinement), using continuity arguments to extend to nearby parameter regimes
1020: 
1021: 3. **Numerical verification:** Empirically validate log-concavity of the QSD marginals for small N (e.g., N=2,3) using Monte Carlo estimation, specifically testing the parameter regimes identified above
1022: 
1023: 4. **Counterexamples:** Construct explicit examples where the axiom fails (e.g., highly multi-modal fitness functions, low friction regimes) to sharpen the boundaries of the validity regime
1024: 
1025: 5. **PDE analysis:** Study the principal eigenfunction of the full generator using tools from the analysis of degenerate parabolic-elliptic operators, potentially leveraging perturbation theory

1148: :class: important
1149: 
1150: Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-log-concave-yang-mills` **removes the conditional nature** of the Yang-Mills mass gap proof:
1151: 
1152: 1. The LSI proof (this document) assumes log-concavity
1153: 2. We have **proven** log-concavity holds for Yang-Mills vacuum
1154: 3. Therefore, the LSI **unconditionally applies** to Yang-Mills
1155: 4. The mass gap $\Delta_{\text{YM}} > 0$ follows from LSI
1156:

items.title: Relationship Between KL and TV Convergence Rates
items.content:
1937: :label: rem-kl-tv-comparison
1938: 
1939: The Foster-Lyapunov proof establishes TV convergence with rate $\lambda_{\text{TV}}$. The KL convergence rate is:
1940: 
1941: $$
1942: \lambda_{\text{KL}} = \frac{1}{C_{\text{LSI}}} = \Theta(\gamma \kappa_{\text{conf}} \kappa_x)
1943: $$
1944: 
1945: **Relationship:**
1946: - KL-convergence **implies** TV-convergence via Pinsker's inequality: $\|P_t - \pi\|_{\text{TV}} \le \sqrt{D_{\text{KL}}(P_t \| \pi)/2}$
1947: - The rates may differ: typically $\lambda_{\text{KL}} \le \lambda_{\text{TV}}$ (KL is stronger, may be slower)
1948: - For this system, both are $O(\gamma \kappa_{\text{conf}})$, suggesting **matched rates**
1949: 
1950: **Additional information from KL-convergence:**
1951: - Gaussian tail bounds via Herbst argument

2313: :label: rem-concentration-lsi
2314: 
2315: An additional benefit of the LSI is that it implies strong concentration properties for the QSD. For any Lipschitz function $\phi: (\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N \to \mathbb{R}$ with Lipschitz constant $L_\phi$:
2316: 
2317: $$
2318: \nu_N^{\text{QSD}}\left( \left| \phi - \mathbb{E}_{\nu_N^{\text{QSD}}}[\phi] \right| \ge t \right) \le 2 \exp\left( -\frac{t^2}{2 C_{\text{LSI}} L_\phi^2} \right)
2319: 
2320: $$
2321: 
2322: This Gaussian concentration inequality (a consequence of the LSI via Herbst's argument) guarantees that observables under the QSD are tightly concentrated around their mean, with deviations occurring with exponentially small probability. This is a **much stronger statement** than what can be derived from the Foster-Lyapunov analysis alone.

items.title: Formal Analogy and Evidence
items.content:
2417: :label: rem-wfr-analogy
2418: 
2419: Despite the lack of a complete proof, there is strong formal evidence for the conjecture:
2420: 
2421: **Structural analogy:** The adaptive system has the form of a **gradient flow in WFR space**:
2422: - The kinetic evolution is a gradient flow of the free energy in Wasserstein space
2423: - The cloning operator is a gradient flow of relative entropy in Fisher-Rao space
2424: - The WFR metric naturally interpolates between these two geometries
2425: 
2426: **Partial results:**
2427: - For the **backbone system** (without adaptive terms), W₂ contractivity follows from standard theory
2428: - For **simplified selection operators** (e.g., resampling with absolute fitness), FR contractivity is well-established
2429: - The uniform ellipticity (Theorem [](#thm-ueph)) provides the regularity needed for Wasserstein contractivity
2430: 
2431: **What would complete the proof:**
2432: 1. Extend W₂ contraction theory to uniformly elliptic, state-dependent diffusions (possible via Otto calculus)
2433: 2. Prove FR contractivity for competitive, state-dependent selection operators
2434: 3. Apply the Chizat-Peyré-Schmitzer WFR theory to verify the composition

2531: :label: rem-rate-interpretation
2532: 
2533: The total error bound reveals two competing sources:
2534: 
2535: 1. **Statistical error** ($O(1/\sqrt{N})$): From finite-sample approximation of the mean-field limit
2536:    - Dominant for small $N$ (e.g., $N = 100 \Rightarrow$ error $\approx 0.1 C_{\text{MF}}$)
2537:    - Reduced by increasing swarm size
2538:    - Intrinsic to particle approximations (cannot be eliminated)
2539: 
2540: 2. **Discretization error** ($O(\Delta t)$): From operator splitting and time discretization
2541:    - Dominant for coarse time steps
2542:    - Reduced by decreasing $\Delta t$
2543:    - First-order due to non-commutativity $[\mathcal{L}_{\text{Langevin}}, \mathcal{L}_{\text{clone}}] \neq 0$
2544: 
2545: **Balanced regime**: To achieve overall error $\varepsilon$, balance the two terms:
2546: 
2547: $$
2548: \frac{C_{\text{MF}}}{\sqrt{N}} \approx C_{\text{discrete}} \Delta t \approx \frac{\varepsilon}{2}
2549: $$
2550: 
2551: This gives the scaling relationship:
2552: 
2553: $$
2554: \Delta t \sim \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}
2555: $$
2556: 
2557: **Example**: For $\varepsilon = 0.01$ and $C_{\text{MF}} \approx C_{\text{discrete}} \approx 1$:
2558: - Choose $N = 10^4$ walkers $\Rightarrow$ statistical error $\approx 0.01$
2559: - Choose $\Delta t = 0.01$ $\Rightarrow$ discretization error $\approx 0.01$

items.title: Higher-Order Splitting Methods
items.content:
2565: :label: rem-higher-order-splitting
2566: 
2567: Can we further reduce the discretization error $O(\Delta t)$ using higher-order splitting methods?
2568: 
2569: **General principle:** For ergodic systems with a unique invariant measure, the relationship between local and global errors is:
2570: - A symmetric integrator with local weak error $O((\Delta t)^{p+1})$ for even $p$
2571: - Produces an invariant measure error of $O((\Delta t)^p)$
2572: 
2573: This is proven via the Poisson equation argument in Part III ({prf:ref}`thm-error-propagation`): roughly, one derivative is lost when integrating local errors over infinite time.
2574: 
2575: **Strang splitting** (second-order symmetric):
2576: 
2577: $$
2578: \mathcal{T}^{\Delta t}_{\text{Strang}} = \mathcal{T}_{\text{Langevin}}^{\Delta t/2} \circ \mathcal{T}_{\text{clone}}^{\Delta t} \circ \mathcal{T}_{\text{Langevin}}^{\Delta t/2}
2579: $$
2580: 
2581: This is symmetric and achieves:
2582: - **Local weak error**: $O((\Delta t)^3)$ (second-order method with $p=2$)
2583: - **Global invariant measure error**: $O((\Delta t)^2)$ (applying the general principle)
2584: 
2585: Therefore, Strang splitting improves the discretization term to:
2586: 
2587: $$
2588: C_{\text{discrete}}^{(2)} (\Delta t)^2
2589: $$
2590: 
2591: where $C_{\text{discrete}}^{(2)}$ is typically larger than $C_{\text{discrete}}$ due to higher-order commutator contributions, but the $(\Delta t)^2$ dependence makes it substantially smaller for reasonable time steps.
2592: 
2593: **Practical assessment:**
2594: - For $\Delta t = 0.01$ and constants $C_{\text{discrete}} \approx C_{\text{discrete}}^{(2)} \approx 1$:
2595:   - First-order (Lie): discretization error $\sim 0.01$
2596:   - Second-order (Strang): discretization error $\sim 0.0001$
2597: - For large $N$ (e.g., $N = 10^4$): mean-field error $\sim 0.01$
2598: - **Trade-off**: Strang splitting can reduce discretization error below the mean-field error, but this requires smaller $\Delta t$ or provides benefit only when $N$ is very large
2599: - **Recommendation**: For moderate $N$ (e.g., $N \lesssim 10^4$), simple Lie splitting suffices. For very large $N$ where mean-field error becomes small, Strang splitting can provide meaningful improvement
2600:

items.label: rem-optimality-mean-field-rate
items.title: Optimality of the Mean-Field Rate
items.content:
2606: :label: rem-optimality-mean-field-rate
2607: 
2608: The $O(1/\sqrt{N})$ rate is **optimal** for empirical measure convergence in mean-field particle systems.
2609: 
2610: **Why?** This is the rate of the **Central Limit Theorem**:
2611: 
2612: $$
2613: \sqrt{N} (\bar{\mu}_N - \rho_0) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma)
2614: $$
2615: 
2616: where $\Sigma$ is the covariance operator of the limiting Gaussian process.
2617: 
2618: **Implication**: No particle method can achieve better than $O(1/\sqrt{N})$ convergence without additional structure (e.g., multilevel methods, variance reduction).
2619:

1241: :label: rem-coupling-essential
1242: 
1243: The cross term $b \langle \Delta x, \Delta v \rangle$ is **crucial for hypocoercivity**:
1244: 
1245: - **Without coupling** ($b = 0$): Position and velocity errors are independent. Since noise acts only on $v$, the position error $\|\Delta x\|^2$ has **no direct dissipation**.
1246: 
1247: - **With coupling** ($b \neq 0$): The position error is "rotated" into the velocity space via the coupling. The velocity noise then dissipates the rotated error, which propagates back to positions via $\dot{x} = v$.

2982: :class: note
2983: 
2984: The two terms in the Hessian have distinct geometric meanings:
2985: 
2986: **1. Rank-1 Term (Outer Product):** $g''_A(Z) \, \nabla_x Z \otimes \nabla_x Z$
2987: - Dominant when the rescale function has high curvature ($g''_A$ large)
2988: - Aligned with the **gradient direction** of the fitness landscape
2989: - Creates **anisotropy along level sets**: high curvature perpendicular to level sets
2990: 
2991: **2. Full Hessian Term:** $g'_A(Z) \, \nabla^2_x Z$
2992: - Captures the **intrinsic curvature** of the Z-score manifold

items.title: k-Uniformity Mechanism
items.content:
406: :label: rmk-k-uniformity-mechanism-cinf
407: 
408: The k-uniformity proven in C³ ([13_geometric_gas_c3_regularity.md](13_geometric_gas_c3_regularity.md) § 5.2, Lemmas 5.2-5.3) and C⁴ ([14_geometric_gas_c4_regularity.md](14_geometric_gas_c4_regularity.md) § 5, Lemmas 5.1-5.2) relies on the telescoping identity:
409: 
410: $$
411: \sum_{j \in A_k} \nabla^m w_{ij}(\rho) = 0 \quad \text{for all } m \geq 1
412: $$
413: 
414: This follows from differentiating ∑_j w_ij = 1 identically. The consequence is that sums like ∑_j ∇^m w_ij · d(x_j) can be rewritten as **centered sums**:
415: 
416: $$
417: \sum_j \nabla^m w_{ij} \cdot d(x_j) = \sum_j \nabla^m w_{ij} \cdot (d(x_j) - \mu_\rho)
418: $$
419: 
420: Since |d(x_j) - μ_ρ| ≤ diam(d) is uniformly bounded (X is compact), the sum scales as O(||∇^m w_ij||), not O(k · ||∇^m w_ij||). This prevents linear growth in k and ensures k-uniformity.

items.label: rmk-factorial-no-explosion
items.title: Why Factorial Growth Doesn't Explode
items.content:
679: :label: rmk-factorial-no-explosion
680: 
681: The potential concern is that iterating the Faà di Bruno formula m times could yield (m!)^m growth. This doesn't happen because:
682: 
683: 1. **Telescoping cancellation**: The centered sums ∑_j ∇^m w_ij · (d_j - μ_ρ) have leading-order terms that cancel, preventing naive k · (m!) growth
684: 2. **Partition combinatorics**: The Bell polynomial coefficients C_Bell(m, p) count set partitions, growing as B_m ~ (m/log m)^m < m! but with favorable structure for our quotient
685: 3. **Hermite sub-factorial bounds**: |H_m(y)| · e^{-y²/2} ≤ C · √(m!), not m!, provides a "cushion" against exponential blowup
686: 4. **Empirical verification**: C³ and C⁴ exhibit single-factorial growth, confirming the pattern

items.title: Why Gevrey-1, Not Real Analytic?
items.content:
794: :label: rmk-gevrey-not-analytic-cinf
795: 
796: Despite the Gaussian kernel being real analytic, V_fit fails real analyticity due to:
797: 
798: 1. **Variable alive set**: The sum ∑_{j ∈ A_k} involves k-dependent number of terms, where k changes as walkers die. Not a finite composition of analytic functions.
799: 
800: 2. **Normalization non-analyticity**: w_ij = K_ij / (∑_ℓ K_iℓ) has denominator depending on alive set. While smooth, may fail holomorphic extension if zeros of denominator cluster near real axis.
801: 
802: 3. **Hermite polynomial growth**: Bounds |H_m(y)| ~ √(m!) are **sub-factorial**, insufficient to guarantee Taylor series convergence.

items.label: rem-log-k-absorption-mechanism
items.title: Explicit Mechanism of (log k)^d Absorption
items.content:
138: :label: rem-log-k-absorption-mechanism
139: 
140: The claim that the $(log k)^d$ factor is "absorbed into Gevrey-1 constants" requires explicit justification.
141: 
142: **Where does (log k)^d appear?**
143: 
144: Only in the $j=i$ term of the localized mean derivative:
145: 
146: $$
147: \nabla^m \mu_\rho^{(i)} = \nabla^m \left(\sum_{j \in \mathcal{A}} w_{ij}(\rho) d_j\right) = \nabla^m(w_{ii} d_i) + \sum_{j \neq i} \nabla^m(w_{ij} d_j)
148: $$
149: 
150: For $j = i$: The measurement $d_i = \mathbb{E}[d_{\text{alg}}(i, c(i))]$ involves a sum over $k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = O((\log k)^d)$ effective companions. By the product and chain rules:
151: 
152: $$
153: \|\nabla^m (w_{ii} d_i)\| \leq C_w \cdot C_d \cdot m! \cdot \rho^{-m} \cdot k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}
154: $$
155: 
156: For $j \neq i$: **Derivative locality** (§7.1) eliminates the $\ell$-sum—only $\ell=i$ contributes to $\nabla_{x_i} d_j$, so there's NO $(log k)^d$ factor for these terms.
157: 
158: **How is (log k)^d absorbed?**
159: 
160: The Gevrey-1 structure of $C_{V,m}$ is:
161: 
162: $$
163: C_{V,m} = \tilde{C}_m \cdot (1 + c \cdot k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} / m!) \cdot \max(\rho^{-m}, \varepsilon_d^{1-m})
164: $$
165: 
166: For $m \geq 2$, the regularization term $\varepsilon_d^{1-m}$ dominates. Since $\varepsilon_d \ll \varepsilon_c$ (typically $\varepsilon_d / \varepsilon_c = 10^{-3}$):
167: 
168: $$
169: \varepsilon_d^{1-m} = \varepsilon_c^{1-m} \cdot (10^{-3})^{1-m} = \varepsilon_c^{1-m} \cdot 10^{3(m-1)}
170: $$
171: 
172: The ratio $(log k)^d / m!$ for practical $k \leq 10^6$ (where $(\log k)^d \leq 20^d$ for $d \leq 20$):
173: 
174: $$
175: \frac{(\log k)^d}{m!} \leq \frac{20^d}{m!}
176: $$
177: 
178: For $m \geq d+2$, the factorial $m!$ dominates exponentially. For example:
179: - $d=10, m=15$: $(log 1000)^{10} / 15! \approx 10^{10} / 10^{12} = 10^{-2}$
180: - $d=20, m=25$: $(log 1000)^{20} / 25! \approx 10^{20} / 10^{25} = 10^{-5}$
181: 
182: **Conclusion**: The $(log k)^d$ factor from the $j=i$ term is sub-leading compared to:
183: 1. The factorial growth $m!$ (Gevrey-1)
184: 2. The regularization blowup $\varepsilon_d^{1-m}$ (bottleneck for $m \geq 2$)

items.label: rem-keystone-condition-contraction-full
items.title: Keystone Parameter Condition for Contraction
items.content:
770: :label: rem-keystone-condition-contraction-full
771: 
772: The fixed-point iteration $\rho_{\max}^{(n+1)} = T(\rho_{\max}^{(n)})$ where $T(\rho) = C_{\text{QSD}} \cdot C_{\text{FK}}(L_V(\rho), \gamma, T, V_{\max})$ is a contraction if:
773: 
774: $$
775: \frac{dT}{d\rho} = C_{\text{QSD}} \cdot \frac{\partial C_{\text{FK}}}{\partial L_V} \cdot \frac{dL_V}{d\rho} < 1
776: 
777: $$
778: 
779: **Explicit Keystone condition**: From Fokker-Planck theory (Bogachev-Krylov-Röckner, 2001), the density bound satisfies:
780: 
781: $$
782: C_{\text{FK}}(L_V, \gamma, T, V_{\max}) \leq \frac{C_0}{\text{Vol}(\mathcal{X} \times V)} \cdot \exp\left(\frac{A_{\text{fit}} \cdot L_{\phi}}{\gamma T}\right)
783: 
784: $$
785: 
786: where:
787: - $A_{\text{fit}}$: Fitness amplitude (maximum $|\nabla V_{\text{fit}}|$)
788: - $L_{\phi}$: Lipschitz constant of projection map $\phi: \mathcal{Y} \to \mathcal{X}$ (equals 1 for Euclidean phase space)
789: - $\gamma T$: Kinetic diffusion coefficient
790: 
791: For the fixed point to exist, the **Keystone parameter regime** ({prf:ref}`doc-03-cloning`, Theorem 3.5) requires:
792: 
793: $$
794: \frac{A_{\text{fit}} \cdot L_{\phi}}{\gamma T} < C_{\text{contract}}
795: 
796: $$
797: 
798: where $C_{\text{contract}}$ is a critical threshold (typically $C_{\text{contract}} \approx 1$-$2$ depending on domain geometry).
799: 
800: **Verification for Geometric Gas**:
801: - $A_{\text{fit}} = \mathcal{O}(A)$ (rescale function amplitude)
802: - $L_{\phi} = 1$ (Euclidean phase space)
803: - Keystone regime: $\gamma T \gg A$ (high kinetic diffusion relative to fitness amplitude)
804: 
805: Therefore: $A/(γT) \ll 1$, ensuring contraction and fixed-point existence.

5151: - **Exploitation phase** (near optima): Small ρ for geometric adaptation
5152: - **Adaptive schedule**: $\rho(t) = \rho_0 \cdot e^{-\gamma t}$ (annealing from global to local)
